sense.name: clean, cleanse, or able to be cleaned
sense.commentary: Note: Includes metaphorical uses. Includes: WASH AWAY, WASH OFF, WASH OUT, WASH UP
sense.examples: Wash the towels please! Wash your face only twice per day. Does this material wash? I could watch my two cats wash each other all day. The nurse washed away the blood. After the paintball war, Joey washes off all the paint. I can't wash all the dirt out of my shirt. Good children wash up before dinner. Her eyes were washed with tears at her grandfather's funeral.

sense.name: Move, form or eliminate by/with water
sense.commentary: Includes: WASH AWAY, WASH DOWN, WASH OUT, WASH UP Note: Includes metaphorical sense of WASH OUT
sense.examples: The swollen river washed away the footbridge. Distilled water will wash minerals from soil. The river washed a ravine into the mountainside. Small waves washed the shore. The body washed down the river. Many shells washed up on the beach after the hurricane. The rain washed out the baseball game.

sense.name: Admit to testing/proof
sense.examples: This silly excuse won't wash in traffic court. I don't that will wash out in proceedings today.

sense.name: apply a thin coating of paint/metal
sense.examples: In between each wash with paint. How to lime wash with paint.

sense.name: accompany food with a lot of liquid
sense.commentary: Is: WASH DOWN Note: Includes metaphorical uses.
sense.examples: Danika ate the burger quickly and washed it down with a pint of beer. He likes to wash his worries down with a nice glass of whiskey.

sense.name: drain of color or vitality; exhaust
sense.commentary: Is: WASH OUT or WASH UP
sense.examples: Wearing yellow totally washes me out. He was washed up after the exam. The harsh detergent washed all the color out of this blouse. Her illness washed her out.
